newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Ayala Land's 9-mth net hailed by analysts.
newsitem.headline: Ayala Land's 9-mth net hailed by analysts.

text.p: Ayala Land Inc's nine-month earnings reported on Monday were hailed by analysts who said it was in line with the consensus estimate for the whole-year of 4.256 billion pesos.
Ayala Land Inc reported its net profit surged by 34 percent to 3.27 billion pesos in the first three quarters compared with 2.43
billion pesos in the year-ago period. Revenues rose by 26 percent to 9.60 billion pesos compared with 7.60 billion pesos in the January to September period last year.

"It's very much in line. No surprises," said Erwin Tan, research head of Abacus Securities who projected a net profit of 4.3 billion pesos for the entire year, 38 percent higher than the 1995 figure of 3.11 billion pesos.
"It's actually in line or even higher than our 4.1 billion-peso forecast," said analyst Zharina Tirol of All Asia Securities Management Corp.
But some analysts said Ayala Land's third quarter performance actually showed a slowing down because most of its developed land had already been sold off.

The third quarter alone churned out a net profit of 730 million pesos compared to the average of 1.25 billion pesos each for the first two quarters. The third quarter is also a 4.7 percent decline from the year-ago quarter of 766 million pesos, analysts said.
Those concerns pulled down Ayala Land's Class B shares by 5.6 percent, or 1.50 pesos, to close at 25.50 pesos on Monday.
Some analysts, however, said that Ayala Land's performance should not be analysed on a quarter-on-quarter basis.

"It has no seasonality. Its earnings depend on its projects which had been moved back in the fourth quarter so that the company can get better pricing," said Colbert Nocom, an analyst of ING Barings Securities.
He said Ayala Land had launched three high-rise projects in the fourth quarter.
Concerns that there could be a cooling down in the real estate sector had made investors take their profits in property stocks in the past two months.

"We're very much concerned that high-rise residential and office buildings would experience a glut in late 1998," said All Asia's Tirol. But she said this segment of the business comprised only 28 percent of Ayala Land's revenues.
"Among the property stocks, it's your safest bet. It is widely diversified into different fields," said Abacus's Tan.
Ayala Land B shares are currently trading at 34.4 times 1996 forecast earnings, a premium to the sector's 20 times. "Ayala Land commands a premium," said Tan.
The firm, a part of the Ayala Corp conglomerate, reported residential, commercial and industrial lot sales made up the bulk or 38 percent of its revenues.
The next contributor was rental revenues which yielded 1.34 billion pesos, or 14 percent of the total.

Ayala Land also booked income in line with the progress of construction of its residential and office building projects, as well as from hotel operations and sales of house-and-lot packages. - Manila newsroom (632) 841-8937
